posts.title: How NASA Astronauts Vote from Space Aboard International Space Station
posts.short_description: NASA astronauts aboard the International Space Station have the opportunity to vote in general elections through absentee ballots or early voting in coordination with the county clerk’s office where they live.   So, how is voting from space possible? Through NASA’s…

posts.title: GPM Celebrates Ten Years of Observing Precipitation for Science and Society
posts.short_description: Introduction On February 27, 2014, the four-ton Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) Core Observatory (CO) spacecraft launched aboard a Japanese H-IIA rocket from Tanegashima Space Center in southern Japan. posts.title: Gateway Stands Tall for Stress Test
posts.short_description: Gateway space station’s Habitation and Logistics Outpost has successfully completed static load testing in Turin, Italy. With this phase of stress testing complete, the module is one step closer to final outfitting ahead of launch to lunar orbit.

posts.title: NASA’s LRO: Lunar Ice Deposits are Widespread
posts.short_description: Deposits of ice in lunar dust and rock (regolith) are more extensive than previously thought, according to a new analysis of data from NASA’s LRO (Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter) mission. Ice would be a valuable resource for future lunar expeditions. Water…

posts.title: Via NASA Plane, Scientists Find New Gamma-ray Emission in Storm Clouds
posts.short_description: There’s more to thunderclouds than rain and lightning. Thunderclouds can produce intense bursts of gamma rays.

posts.title: What’s Up: October 2024 Skywatching Tips from NASA
posts.short_description: A new comet is passing through the inner solar system! Time will tell if it’s the brightest of the year, once it appears in twilight after about Oct. 14.
